title: Jack Shantry
text:
Jack David Shantry (born 29 January 1988) is a former English <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er who played <a href="county%20cricket">county cricket</a> for <a href="Worcestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Worcestershire</a>.
Shantry played for Shropshire Under-17s as early as July 2004, scoring 64 at the top of the <a href="batting%20order%20%28cricket%29">order</a> against Yorkshire Under-17s.
He made several further appearances for Shropshire Under-17s, and also played for <a href="Shrewsbury%20Cricket%20Club">Shrewsbury Cricket Club</a>, appearing in the <a href="Cockspur%20Cup">Cockspur Cup</a> and making an appearance against <a href="Kidderminster%20Victoria%20Cricket%20Club">Kidderminster Victoria</a> in the <a href="Birmingham%20and%20District%20Premier%20League">Birmingham and District Premier League</a>.
In 2007 and 2008, Shantry progressed to a mixture of senior cricket at <a href="minor%20counties">minor counties</a> level with <a href="Shropshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Shropshire County Cricket Club</a> and Second XI cricket for Worcestershire. He took 7/34 for Worcestershire Second XI against <a href="Leicestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Leicestershire II</a> in June 2008,
and scored 88 for Shropshire against <a href="Wales%20Minor%20Counties%20Cricket%20Club">Wales Minor Counties</a> in August of the same year.
Between these two feats, in July, he had appeared for Shropshire in the final of the Resource Bank Twenty20 Cup, which they lost to a star-studded <a href="Lashings%20World%20XI">Lashings World XI</a> side despite Shantry's 3/11.
Shantry made his senior debut for Worcestershire in a <a href="Pro40">Pro40</a> match against <a href="Essex%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Essex</a> at <a href="Castle%20Park%20Cricket%20Ground">Colchester</a> on 23 August 2009, taking the wicket of <a href="Ravi%20Bopara">Ravi Bopara</a> and not batting.
Two days later, he made his maiden appearance in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> when he was selected for Worcestershire's <a href="County%20Championship">County Championship</a> clash with <a href="Nottinghamshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Nottinghamshire</a> at <a href="New%20Road%2C%20Worcester">New Road</a>. In a drawn game, Shantry claimed the wickets of <a href="Bilal%20Shafayat">Bilal Shafayat</a> and <a href="Mark%20Ealham">Mark Ealham</a>, but was <a href="Leg%20before%20wicket">lbw</a> for nought in his only innings.
He retained his place in the side in both one-day and four-day cricket, and so his <a href="club%20cricket">club cricket</a> appearances, now for <a href="Walsall%20Cricket%20Club">Walsall</a>, became less frequent.
Shantry pressed his claims for a regular place in the side in his first game of the 2010 season, a non-first-class warm-up match against <a href="Bradford/Leeds%20University%20Centre%20of%20Cricketing%20Excellence">Bradford/Leeds UCCE</a>. He claimed 5–18 in the first innings, and opened the bowling in the second innings, taking a wicket with the first ball of the innings and finishing with 7–47, to complete a match haul of 12 wickets for 65. Worcestershire went on to win the game.
In September 2014, he scored his maiden first-class century (and took ten wickets in a first-class match for the first time) in a victory over Surrey that guaranteed Worcestershire promotion to Division 1.
In June 2018, Shantry announced his retirement from all cricket with immediate effect, due to ongoing back injuries.
